Fields.DialogueText: *KABOOM*
*RATATAT*
Hold steady, men! Don't give them an inch!
*KABOOM*
Stick to my plan and...
*FOOTSTEPS*
Captain. The best laid plans of mice and men, something, something.
Cossack...
Leave everything to me.
Cossack, wait!
You're not even Scottish!
@BATTLE
Until the day I die I will marvel at such reckless disregard for not only your own well-being, but that of everyone around you as well.
Your plan was good in theory, Captain. But if someone chooses to point a gun in my face, I will not be responsible for my actions.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you're on our side, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: As am I. You may yet to have found your inner warrior, but with my help, you'll get there someday.

Fields.MenuText: I'd like to hold more respect as your superior.

Fields.DialogueText: And I'd like the war to finish, but we can't all--! ... Apologies, Captain. You're right. I will try harder to respect your authority.

Fields.MenuText: Don't get yourself hurt.

Fields.DialogueText: Who do you think you're talking to?!
Now that the Morganas have been sufficiently dealt with, what say we retire to--?
*MEOW*
AH!
It seems he was worried about you.
Let him worry. I thought we had decided to cast that... THING overboard.
He's not hurting anybody. The day he aims a gun in your face I give you my word I will have him walk the plank.
Joking aside, Captain, a black cat will bring no good fortune to this ship...
Perhaps if you were to paint this spectre of bad luck you fear so much in a new light, your worries would lessen.
How do you propose I do that?
Well, this "black cat" has been aboard for sometime now. It is rude to not refer to people by their names, wouldn't you agree?
But its a stray, Captain. It doesn't have any... Why are you looking at me like that...?
I've never named anything before. Names foster attachment, which is something I'd rather do without.

Fields.MenuText: You don't plan on making any connections until the day you die?

Fields.DialogueText: At least until the war is over... Naturally, as you are my captain, certain exceptions can be made. I draw the line at accepting anything with more than two legs.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. You probably couldn't handle taking care of it.

Fields.DialogueText: Ho ho, Captain, if you think reverse psychology will work on me, you're absolutely right!

Fields.MenuText: Shall we revert to calling each other by number from now on, then?

Fields.DialogueText: Why stop there? Perhaps we could just grunt at one another when requiring assistance.
*ALARM*
*MEOW*
He's scared, see? I guess it was too much to expect the great Cossack to be able to protect both her crew and a cat.
I'll wipe that grin off your face momentarily, Captain. And, when I do, I'll name the ever-living HELL out of this cat!
@BATTLE
I suppose, in some ways, cats can be bringers of good fortune.
How do you figure?
"Owls, and swallows, and other birds fly upon their bodies, and upon their heads, and cats in like manner. Whereby you may know that they are no gods. Therefore fear them not."
I'm not following.
The fear of the unknown, the bad luck spectres that haunt us all, can be seen as farcical due to the associations they have with our typical animal life.
I see... so in a sense, owls and cats imply a sort of normalcy to these otherworldly apparitions you fear so much.
*ALARM*
Thank goodness. This isn't a book club, Captain. No time to get complacent! To battle!
@BATTLE
Considering your renewed faith, why not name him after a favored person from history?
Do you have any suggestions?

Fields.MenuText: Joseph?
Abraham?
Judas?

Fields.DialogueText: Too blasphemous, all things considered.
You're not helping my anxiety, Captain...
God first revealed himself to Abraham. In a way, I do enjoy being referred to with such authority... but a part of me worries my eternal soul may suffer should I indulge the feeling too long.
How about Moses?
Moses?
He fought back against tyranny wherever it stood. I'm not saying you plan to do anything malicious to me, but you carry a similar rebellious spirit that could be passed down to your offspring.
Moses... A parting of the sea could come in handy every now and again, I suppose.
What do you say, little one?
*MEOW* *MEOW*
I think he likes it.
Is that a smile I see, Cossack?
It must be your imagination. Quickly, we must make preparations for the cat-- for Moses's living quarters.
We'll need a bed, some wet food, a scratching post...
You've changed your tune.
It can't be helped considering that SOMEONE decided to force an infant into my care.
Let me make it up to you. There should be some kind of weapons vendor in this port. How about an upgrade?
We've just agreed to take another life into our care. Can we really afford to be spending so much?

Fields.MenuText: Leave it to me. I'll see everything works out.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not going to complain about increasing my firepower!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you're right...

Fields.DialogueText: Worry not, Captain. I'm more than capable of handling a Morgana or twenty in my current state!
Let's finish up here and head back to the ship. I have a feeling those Morganas that were tailing us may make our exit a little difficult.
Worry not, Captain. Moses and I can handle any foe!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You can't put a price on life.

Fields.DialogueText: Even cat lives.
That cat is really growing on you, huh?
Just because I'm allowing him to dine with me does not mean I have been completely won over.
Still, it's a big step from before.
I think you are partly to blame, Captain.
In what way?
As you know, I have had my... disagreements with authority figures in the past.
Similarly to how I had painted those in such positions as black or white, I think I've done the same with other preconceived notions I held.

Fields.MenuText: It's never too late to change onself.

Fields.DialogueText: So I've come to realize.

Fields.MenuText: Did you feel that way about me when we first met?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't particularly want to answer that question and, if you really think about it, I don't think you want me to either.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could start busting down some of your other superstitions.

Fields.DialogueText: One step at a time, Captain. This is all moving too fast.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Quickly, Cossack!
I'm right behind you!
@BATTLE
Where did most of your superstitions stem from? Are they Russian or British?
Most are British. We are famed for our unique superstitions.
I've never been all that superstitious, so they must have passed me by.
I'd be happy to catch you up. What type of omen would you like to hear about?

Fields.MenuText: Umbrellas.
Magpies.

Fields.DialogueText: One for sorrow, two for joy, three for a girl, four for a boy, five for silver, six for gold, seven for a secret never to be told.
So, if I see three magpies I can expect to be married, whereas six would see me very wealthy?
That's right! Magpies mate for life, so if you see one on its own it's either lost its partner or hasn't found one. You can fight this bad luck by saluting it and saying "Good morning, Mr. Magpie."
It is very bad luck to open an umbrella indoors. Why do you think I always dry mine out here on the deck?

Fields.MenuText: Mirrors.

Fields.DialogueText: Smashing a mirror will bring you seven years' bad luck. Apparently, there is a way to reduce your sentence by praying to the lunar calendar cycle, but that is far too pagan-like for my tastes.
*ALARM*
That is... certainly a lot to remember...
Morganas, Captain!
Maybe your bad luck hasn't dissipated as much as we'd thought.
On the contrary. It is the Morganas who are in for a spell of bad luck!
@BATTLE
New orders, Cossack. We're to take down a legion of thriving Morganas surrounding Narvik.
I see. Norway... I've never been.
There is also word that a multi-man team has been taken prisoner in Jøssingfjord. We are to retrieve all personnel en route to Narvik.
I'm sure certain liberties can be taken considering wartime--
ALIVE.
*Sigh* Have it your way...

Fields.MenuText: Is that going to be a problem?

Fields.DialogueText: Casualties of war are par for the course, Captain. That being said, I'll do my best to adhere to your orders.

Fields.MenuText: What do you know about Norway?

Fields.DialogueText: Very little. Aside from names, this will be an entirely new experience for me. Still, I am confident of my ability to adapt to any situation.

Fields.MenuText: This could be dangerous.

Fields.DialogueText: Men's lives are at stake, Captain. Granted, I have no enthusiasm to save these people over taking out some unruly Morganas, but the principle still stands. We must make moves.
Very well. We will begin preparations and leave at dawn.
I'll fetch Moses's travel bag!
Are you sure it's wise to bring such an emotional anchor along with us?
Moses isn't some everyday witch's curse, Captain. Trust me, we're going to need all the luck we can scavenge!
*ALARM*
Let's see how your feline fusilier helps us in the upcoming battle before arming him to the teeth.
Uh-huh...
And if things really go south, we can always arm him with a small automatic pistol!
Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE
Only a few more days until we reach the front.
I was lucky enough to serve the Royal Navy. I'm sure such fortune will grace us wherever I go. Best to keep me close by, Captain.
If I wasn't already sure you would jump at the first sign of battle, those words might be a little more comforting.
Ha! You know me too well, Captain. I trust you can keep yourself alive long enough for me to return.

Fields.MenuText: So, you prefer serving under the British Navy?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. I couldn't face the persecution of the Soviet Cossacks.

Fields.MenuText: Will you continue to fight so relentlessly even after the war concludes?

Fields.DialogueText: That depends on the victor! Should the Morganas truly overpower us, I suppose I will continue fighting until my dying breath.
However, should we emerge on top, it might be nice to finally put my feet up. Although I can see myself becoming bored with such tedium very quickly.

Fields.MenuText: What spawned this love of battle for you?

Fields.DialogueText: It's less a love of battle and more a love of results. I will do whatever it takes to ensure my mission is carried out successfully.
It just so happens that, oftentimes, this means I must go on a rampage now and again.
*ALARM*
We must have entered enemy territory. The battles will be coming fast and relentless from now on, it seems.
Just the way I like it!
@BATTLE
Stay sharp, Cossack. We're in uncharted territory. Enemy waters.
I don't think you should phrase it as such, Captain. After all, the people of Norway have done nothing to earn our mistrust.
Right you are. It is the Morganas who we should look towards for retribution.
*ALARM*
Speaking of which, we appear to have hit a roadblock.
Don't worry, Captain. We will finish this mission by passing through whoever stands in our way.
@BATTLE
There, in the distance! I think I see land. What beautiful scenery.

Fields.MenuText: I never expected you to be such a fan of fauna.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't judge books by their covers, Captain. The fresh smile of a sunflower is all the reason I need to drive back these landscape-destroying invaders.

Fields.MenuText: I would have thought English soil had desensitized you to all things wilderness.

Fields.DialogueText: England's plant life is a sight to behold... but, with the increasingly short warmer seasons, there is very little time to enjoy it.

Fields.MenuText: Do you have a favorite flower?

Fields.DialogueText: It would have to be the smiling face of the sunflower. I've always been slightly embarrassed to purchase a bouquet just for myself, unfortunately...
Good eye, Cossack. There is a town coming into focus.
We should resupply for the mission ahead. We'll probably be forced to do without another pit stop for some time.
My thoughts exactly. Men, plot a course!
I think that's just about everything we'll need.
I've been wondering, do you think we have enough men for the job?
What do you mean?
If we are overrun due to a lack of numbers, we may end up becoming prisoners of war ourselves.
I hope you aren't thinking I'll go quietly into the night, Captain. But if you really are worried, I don't think bolstering our forces would be any detriment.

Fields.MenuText: Just to be safe.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll ask around. Perhaps we can find some ex-sailors looking to stretch their sea legs.

Fields.MenuText: No, you're right. We'll be fine.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry, Captain. Moses and I will keep you safe.
*ALARM*
That sounded like our alarm! I can hear it from all the way out here!
Quickly! We can't afford to lose any more time than we have already!
Yes, Captain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You're right. I'm underestimating you as a force multiplier.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm rather good at multiplication, you'll find.
More enemies inbound, Captain!
*BOOM*
Don't give them an inch!
@BATTLE
We appear to be in the clear... for now.
Don't look so glum, Captain. This is good news. The more enemies that appear, the closer we must be to the stronghold.
Stronghold? You do realize we aren't invading Wonderland or Oz.
We're in a war between man and monster, Captain! If that doesn't spell "adventure," I don't know what does!

Fields.MenuText: You're enjoying the war?

Fields.DialogueText: I wouldn't go that far, Captain. I enjoy giving people their just desserts, but I wouldn't go out of my way to harm someone innocent.

Fields.MenuText: Still, the greater the enemy, the greater the peril.

Fields.DialogueText: And, the greater the chance of something exciting happening!

Fields.MenuText: Man and monster, huh? Before the Morganas came, when we were on the advent of war, would you have said the same thing?

Fields.DialogueText: That question is a little too rich for my blood. Whatever previous alignments any of us may have had, the time has come to band together to defeat an even greater foe.
Cossack! Can you see that ship? That's the vessel we're to plunder. Our missing men are aboard that destroyer!
Then it looks like it's finally time for me to let loose a little!
There! A prisoner transport, dead in the water! Finally, a little action!
Wait, Cossack! I think we should get close and covertly board the ship instead. Our men can fight while the two of us evacuate the prisoners.
Captain, you can't expect me to turn tail and run at such a--
We'll need your strength on the front lines to defend the lives of the hostages if necessary. The men can handle themselves without you.
But, Captain--
Do you trust me, Cossack?!

Fields.MenuText: Your strengths are better suited for this.

Fields.DialogueText: My strengths as a rampaging destroyer?
You're much more than that and we both know it.

Fields.MenuText: That's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: You know how I feel about orders.
Not an order from superior to worker. An order from... one friend to the other to see sense.

Fields.MenuText: This is the right call. I promise you.

Fields.DialogueText: If you're so insistent...
Fine. But Moses is coming with me as a witness in case this all blows up in our faces. I'll inform the men to begin their advance.
I knew you cared.
Don't push it, Captain.
@BATTLE
Quickly, Captain! We barely made it out of there alive!
I thought you said you were going to go quietly!
I agreed to come, but we were rumbled! I had to fight our way to safety!
I shouldn't be complaining. Without you, I'd have been locked up with the rest of them.
What of the prisoners?
They're fine. The captain gave his thanks before passing out. It seems he held out for far longer than he could handle to ensure his crew remained untouched.
Quickly, we'll send them to be checked.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you for listening to me, Cossack.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't take too much praise. I did lose sight of myself when it counted most. Still, thank you.

Fields.MenuText: Zero casualties. Mission success.

Fields.DialogueText: Not yet, Captain...

Fields.MenuText: They should make a speedy recovery.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd be lying if I said this rush of defeating an opponent without losing anyone didn't come with its own thrill.
I think you've earned the right to go a little wild.
I'll take such an opportunity with open arms, Captain!
@BATTLE
No rest for the wicked. Onward to Narvik.
It was only Morganas plaguing this town, right? No hostages?
That's right.
Then I'm sure you won't mind if I skip the espionage this time around.
Naturally.
You won't regret it, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I'd be inclined to see the full extent of your power one day.

Fields.DialogueText: If something I care about is ever in danger, I'm not sure the world could handle such firepower.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you listened to me just this once.

Fields.DialogueText: Your ideas aren't... all terrible. I can see the value of tactical espionage every now and again.

Fields.MenuText: I better not regret it.

Fields.DialogueText: Life is too short for regrets, Captain. Even if you are unhappy with my performance, try to at least marvel at the majesty of the explosions!
*ALARM*
What is this? A recon party?
Whatever they're doing out here, they won't be doing it for long!
@BATTLE
Don't hesitate, men! This is the final wave! Once we deal with these pests, the town of Narvik will be free!
I've still got plenty of energy left, Captain! Let me--!
*REEEEEEEEEAAAAAAAAAK*
We've been flanked!
My necklace!
*PLOP*
Damn Morganas. You will rue the day you ever stood in my way...
@BATTLE
They're retreating. For now, anyway...
My necklace...
I've sent some men to try and forage it but...
I'm no child, Captain. I know the fate of those lost at sea...

Fields.MenuText: What was inside?

Fields.DialogueText: A prayer. I must have shown it to you before.
What kind of prayer?
I'd rather not get into it right now...

Fields.MenuText: We can buy you a new necklace.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate the kind words, but... this was a very special item. It won't be replaced so easily.

Fields.MenuText: Better your necklace than your life.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose. Although, had my life been taken, I could have at least been together with my amulet in the afterlife. That necklace is going to have a LONG wait in heaven before I die.
*ALARM*
But I thought...?
Stragglers. Apparantly, they didn't get the memo to retreat.
I see.
Hey, chin up. How about I give you permission to let go of the brakes for a while. A free-for-all Morgana destruction rally.
... I'd like that, Captain.
*COLLAPSE*
I'm exhausted... We succeed in our operations, but at what cost to our mental and physical health?!
I never thought I'd say this, but... I think I'd like to take a little break...
*mew*
Oh, Moses survived... That's good news.
How callous. Moses may have played a part in our escape. You should be more thankful.
It wasn't so long ago that you couldn't stand the thing.
Yes, well...! People's feelings can change, all right?
Still, I like your idea of a holiday. Perhaps we can take stock of the damage while stretching our legs.
Is there anything in particular you'd like to do?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could pick up some flowers to patch the gaping holes in our hull.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd love to!

Fields.MenuText: Anything other than a fight with another Morgana!

Fields.DialogueText: Preach!

Fields.MenuText: Something quiet... and relaxing... and quiet...

Fields.DialogueText: More comforting words were never spoken.
*ALARM*
One more for the road?
I can handle one final encore if you can!
@BATTLE
Several Morganas are blocking our entrance, Captain.
It seems our fated path has already been drawn. We'll never be shot of them! We'll have to push through!
Aye-aye!
@BATTLE
Now that the Morganas have been dealt with, we can finally let our hair down for a short while at least.
We expended a lot of our firepower in that last fight. Perhaps we could take this time to resupply as well.

Fields.MenuText: Good idea.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm full of them, aren't I?!

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps next time.

Fields.DialogueText: Tomorrow never comes, Captain! Best we live in the moment!
Let's see if we can pick up some flowers while we're here.
Flowers?
You spoke so fervently about your taste for them. I thought they could brighten up the ship a little.
Wonderful! Come on, Captain! There's a flower shop just down the coast!

Fields.MenuText: Already taken care of. Consider it tax.

Fields.DialogueText: We help those who help us.
This little respite has filled me with energy! I could take on ten... no, twenty Morganas in my current state!
It looks like you'll soon get your chance. It seems our exit has been blocked!
I wouldn't say no to being trapped here, but it's the principle of the matter. No one tells me where I can and can't go!
@BATTLE
Everything looks to be loaded up.
One last thing. Here, these are for you.
What the... a bouquet?
I recall you said once you were too embarrassed to buy one for yourself, so I thought I'd save you the trouble.
I... you... but...!

Fields.MenuText: It's only flowers.

Fields.DialogueText: ONLY flowers?!

Fields.MenuText: This is the right kind, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Sunflowers, yes... You remembered...

Fields.MenuText: Should I not have?

Fields.DialogueText: No, not at all! It's just...
Quickly, you need to find a vase for these.
Right! I've become a mother to two in the past few weeks without ever asking! Moses and the flowers a require a lot of upkeep, you know..
I'll finish up here. Go ahead and--
*Peck*
What was that for?
Just a little token of my appreciation. Don't get used to it.
Captain! There you are!
What seems to be the problem, Cossack?
Moses has gone AWOL. The only clue I have of his whereabout is this!
A piece of paper with a black paw print on it?
It's the Black Spot, Captain! A mark of death administered upon doomed sailors!
Firstly, we're not pirates. Secondly, I'm sure the Black Spot was given to those with a target on their head from OTHER pirates. It isn't a curse that--
Moses could be in grave danger and you're talking semantics?! We have to find him before he gets hurt!

Fields.MenuText: When did you last see him?

Fields.DialogueText: This morning. He was in my room before I sent him to try and... borrow some snacks from your quarters.

Fields.MenuText: Was he acting strangely before this happened?

Fields.DialogueText: No stranger than usual for the literal manifestation of bad luck.

Fields.MenuText: Have you looked everywhere?

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't looked anywhere! I've been too distraught!
This ink is the same kind I use when writing formal letters. All those years studying calligraphy might have paid off. We have a lead, at least.
*ALARM*
Good eye, Captain. Let's take care of these Morganas and scour the ship for paw prints!
@BATTLE
The footprints have lead us down here but...
No sign of Moses... Oh, Captain, what are we going to do?
You're taking this to the heart a lot more than I thought you'd be.
No matter what I may say about omens and curses, I would not wish death, pain, or injury upon anyone. Aside from the Morganas, of course.

Fields.MenuText: Is that due to your religious beliefs?

Fields.DialogueText: It's due to my nature of being alive myself. I know the pain of loss all too well.

Fields.MenuText: Is that due to your role as a top-class destroyer?

Fields.DialogueText: Partly, I suppose. If Moses were a junior Belle, taken under my wing, I would be responsible for their well-being.
I could never look another Morgana in the eye if I allowed them to do harm to my subordinates. I'm sure, as a captain yourself, you can understand.

Fields.MenuText: Is that due to your kind-hearted compassion?

Fields.DialogueText: Is that sarcasm peppering your words, Captain? If not, then I appreciate your ability to see through to the heart of my actions.
The footprints lead over here.
Another piece of paper?
One of the crew must have dropped a file down here. There's some markings across it that look to have been trodden in by Moses. From this angle, it almost looks like...
A thirteen! He's written the number thirteen! Could Moses be leading us down a path of sin?!
I was going to say it looked like a smiling face, but I suppose we each see what we want to...
*ALARM*
Quickly, Captain. The prints lead back up to the deck. We can clash with the Morganas on the way!
@BATTLE
Luckily, Moses wasn't out here. He could have been seriously injured during that last battle.
Still, we're nowhere closer to finding out where he's gotten to...

Fields.MenuText: We'll find him, don't worry.

Fields.DialogueText: I trust that as a team, we can accomplish anything, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we should split up and search.

Fields.DialogueText: No, Captain. There was a reason I came to you before searching myself. I trust your tactical mind more than anyone I've ever met before.

Fields.MenuText: I'm starting to worry now as well...

Fields.DialogueText: If Moses managed to win ME over, I'm surprised it has taken you this long to come around.
Try to think of the situation he was in before he went missing. What were you about to do?
Let me think... *mrarw* *mew* *mew*
When I said "think about Moses' situation," I didn't mean from his perspective. You really flip a switch when it comes to all this superstitious--
The mess hall! It's almost dinner time!
*ALARM*
Great! We can work up an appetite before the victory course!
@BATTLE
Moses!
*MEOW*
See? Safe and sound. Although his dirtied paws have rendered that meal inedible...
The cook must have given him something to stop his whimpering. Thank goodness!

Fields.MenuText: This is what you get for trying to "borrow" from me without asking.

Fields.DialogueText: Karmic retribution is a foul mistress. I humbly apologise, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Tie a leash around him next time.

Fields.DialogueText: It's cruel to keep a cat contained. We're very similar in that regard!

Fields.MenuText: Hurry and get him cleaned up.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't you think his paw print would make an excellent seal for your next formal letter?
*ALARM*
Something's been playing on my mind for a while now. This entire scenario started because Moses found his way into my room, correct?
I don't think this is the time, Captain! We're under attack!
But... My door was locked... How did you...
*MEOW*
Maybe you really are a special kind of--
CAPTAIN!
Coming!
@BATTLE
I'm going to be bankrupt...
That ink your offspring tampered with was very expensive. I expect it to be repaid in full.
I was planning to purchase a new gun while we were docked. Do you think the budget will allow for both?

Fields.MenuText: I think you've learnt your lesson.

Fields.DialogueText: Phew! I mean... thank you very much, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You should have thought about that before you took in a child.

Fields.DialogueText: You're punishing me for choosing to care for a little one?! Times are changing, Captain. I may have to take you to a tribunal to defend my rights!
Those Morganas look as though they're trying to ambush us.
I was thinking the same thing. With your fresh ink, maybe you could draw us a way out of this.
Nobody likes a smart mouth, Cossack. Now, with me!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Orders of magnitude of difference. I wouldn't worry.

Fields.DialogueText: Right. Nonetheless... I'll keep an eye on him.
*MEOW*
It's quite serene today.
I was thinking the same thing.
I know we were supposed to discuss battle tactics, but...
I was thinking the same thing...
I'd like it to always stay like this. Me, you, and Moses. We could travel the world, see the sights, forge our precious memories...

Fields.MenuText: I'll make it a reality for you someday, Cossack.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll hold you to that.

Fields.MenuText: War is hell.

Fields.DialogueText: I love the rush of battle. I love completing my duty. But I never would have thought moments like this could be just as intoxicating. You are to thank for that, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: What should we do first?

Fields.DialogueText: We should return to Norway! The people may throw a parade in our honor for liberating them from the Morganas!
*ALARM*
Into the killing field again, it seems.
Don't think me washed up, Captain. If you'll only offer me brief windows like this to enjoy your and Moses's company away from the battlefield, that is all I need.
@BATTLE
Morganas approaching!
Let's show them why we're a trio they don't want to mess with! Isn't that right?!
*MEOW!*
@BATTLE
I'm impressed, Cossack. You held the line quite nicely in that nice fight. I didn't lose sight of you immediately once the battle had begun.
I've always been inclined to fight for what I believe in, fight for what's right. However, those things aren't as tangible as either you or Moses.

Fields.MenuText: What are you saying?

Fields.DialogueText: Now that there is something in front of me that I want to protect, I can see the importance of following your orders, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: So you'll be listening to me from now on?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe on occasion...

Fields.MenuText: I want to protect you two as well.

Fields.DialogueText: As much as I would not like to place a bet on you over a fleet of Morganas, I appreciate the thought.
Well then, onwards into the horizon, Cossack. You, me, and Moses. Do you think we'll make it to the end?
I'm sure we will, Captain. Even if that means slamming down a full stop to put an end to the war ourselves!
*MEOW!!*
